Originally released by Channel Four (Great Britain), 2014.

Day of the Dead Introduction (3:09) -- Cultural and Religious Blend (3:05) -- Mitla (2:20) -- Aztec and Christian Iconography (2:16) -- Etla Festivities (3:15) -- Ofrendas and Angelitos (3:24) -- Spiritual Communication (3:28) -- Remembering Angelitos (4:00) -- All Saint's Day (2:16) -- Day of the Dead Lunch (2:28) -- Muerteada Band (2:58) -- Shifting Religious Views (3:19) -- All Saint's Night (3:54) -- All Soul's Day (2:05) -- Day of the Dead Dichotomy (3:53) -- Credits: Festivals: Day of the Dead, Mexico (0:31) -- LIBR 251 (0:00)
Access limited to UNC Chapel Hill-authenticated users.

Festivals of life nourish us with ancient rituals in a fast-changing world, covering all facets of the human condition, the changing seasons, weddings, coming of age ceremonies, births and deaths, the worship of gods and the battle against evil spirits. This film showcases Mexico's Day of the Dead celebrations that unite the living and the dead in feasting, dancing and decoration. In Oaxaca City, local artists create sand tapestries and enter an altar competition. Families gather at the public cemetery to clean the graves of loved ones and make offerings. In Etla, muerteadas, or street parades, last all night as rival bands engage in mock battles. Join a local family for a traditional lunch of chicken and mole, and learn about Aztec and Spanish religious customs that blended to form today's Da de los Muertos festival of remembrance.
Title from distributor's description (Films Media Group, March 10, 2016)

Cf. A izdavalos to v Rige 1918-1944 / IU. Abyzov.
"Illiustrirovanny zhurnal literatury, politiki i sovremenno zhizni"; added subtitle, <1927, no. 6-16>: "revue russe hebdomadaire 'Novaia Niva'."

Savine Collection copy of 1927, no. 8 bears inscription on caption: "Dorogo odamlenno Poposhie i dorogomu Demianchiku--moim pupsikam--na dobruiu pamiat ot sestritsy-krasavitsy, to-is [illegible signature]. Fevral 1927-VI."
Savine Collection copy of 1927, no.13 bears name and address of former owner (Andr Savine's father?) on cover: "Waldemar Savine, 100 avenue Ed. Vaillant, Billancourt (Seine)."
Several Savine Collection copies stitched together bear stamp of "Biblioteka 80-go Ochaga M.P. g. Aner."
In Russian, with some stories translated from English.
